review_title: Lack of support but a lot of autonomy
pros: Little to no micromanaging, plenty of autonomy, exposure to working within county mental health.
cons: Upper management seems to lack attention to what staff need to perform their jobs effectively/efficiently and investment in trainings appropriate to each staff's role. Staff in the toughest programs are severely under-paid. This, along with a lack of support/training makes it a difficult work environment and is felt throughout the agency. There is a high turn over rate due to burn out and low morale.

pros: Strength, awareness, communication, team worker, reliable, honest,
cons: I do not have cons

pros: Working with the participants and impacting their lives.
cons:
A toxic environment where they let my program director go without warning. Told us that he wasn't making his numbers. The senior director came in after they let my boss go and told us a whole lot of things that didn't seem right. I now have two new bosses to replace my old one and neither one of them can make a decision.

The organization fosters fear and the unknown. There is no HR department so I have no recourse but to write my review here. They don't give raises and paychecks are sometimes late and partial. Also, I am expected to pay for supplies for my clients out of my own pocket and wait for reimbursement and it's a real struggle. 

Senior management, low pay, no or minimal raises, no holidays off, no HR dept.

review_title: Underpaid and limited opportunities to advance
pros: There is a decent amount of training opportunities and programs that work directly with vulnerable populations of San Diego County. You will likely learn as you go along the job because of the demands of the specific program you end up working under. They welcome and support diversity, trauma-informed care, and meeting the client they are at....as long as you hit your productivity of course.
cons: Most likely you will spend a long time in the position you are at without any opportunities to advance as a clinician. I've heard clinicians who become licensed receive insultingly low raises to compensate the fact that they are now licensed (which is an incredible accomplishment). If you don't advocate for your own needs, they will just pay you the lowest amount possible.

review_title: Great Starting point, DO NOT GET STUCK
job_title: Behavior Specialist in Chula Vista, CA
pros:
There were a number of pros. for being a new grad and getting my feet wet in both social work and education, NA was a ripe opportunity to really learn if you like it. The people you work with are all great and can be some of your best friends. You also get at least 1 free meal with a shift, get to work with teenagers and actually feel like you change the world. 

The work/life balance was great, if you want to work 40 hrs a week, great, go for it kid. if you wanna work 56 hrs sure why not, we are always short staffed. OH, WORK YESTERDAY KILLED YOU? CALL IN AND TAKE A DAY OFF FOR "mental health day" ONCE A MONTH.
cons: So this company hires 2 types of employees, recent grads, or therapists. All the managers have been there for 5+ years before they were promoted. The nature of the job is violent by nature and sometimes you may get hurt when a client really doesnt like you and may throw a brick at you or try and punch you etc. In my time i was bit, scratched, punched, kicked, spit on, and stabbed. You can easily get "stuck" in this job because it offers what a 21 year old new grad would love, hang out and supervise teenagers? why not? You get stuck with a low pay and no room to move up until someone above you leaves.

review_title: Nice working here, good work environment
pros: NPO exposure and real life experience
cons: Nothing, very good company. No cons

review_title: provide in home behavioral coaching for children and youth
job_title: Therapeutic behavioral coach in San Diego, CA
pros: flexible time off, visit clients in the home, collaborate with case managers, friendly workspace
cons: hours vary, low pay, paperwork

review_title: A hostile environment for graduated college Dreamers and children
job_title: Developmental Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Once the overnight shif is over, you can feel the warming California sun rise cheering you up ;-)
You get to know very few valuable people, who really care about the children and their personal problems.
You learn that all the human resources and managemnt courses that you learned in the books do not work in the real world at all.
For a recent college graduate , it could be the first and last opportunity to make a better world by changing the whole system........
cons:
Most of the administrative staff do not do much about issues regarding the arrogant, and authoritative behavior expressed by some supervisors and team leaders against staff and the children.
The overnight shift is a living hell with the lunatics, hiperactives (by snorting coke), obsesive compulsive, and bipolar staff .
I would say that the MONEY factor is the main reason why most people try to stay there, even though the income per hour is very low, if you want to live by fancy California standards.
For a recent college graduate, certainly the is not the best place to work for the first time, because you get to see on first hand the nasty and meaner side of people at work. So all your good intentions and ideals to make a better society are pretty fast trashed down.

pros: Lots of free time, lots of training
cons: high level stress at times, no support, inconsistency with everything, high turnover rate, pay is really bad

review_title: I've done it all. What a nightmare!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
Training and a handful of strong coworkers.
You will get a lot of raw experience in the field.
I really can't think of anything else to say.
cons:
Management, unfair labor practices, being lied to by management, late paychecks, verbal and emotional abuse from managers. A "confidential" accounting department??? That's a big red flag.

Need a YTD statement? It takes 3 months, countless written requests and begging and pleading. 

I'm sad the kids are the ultimate victims. We can always go find a new job...the kids are the ones who end up suffering. They need stability, consistency, predictable staff they can trust. Management has so many problems they can't keep a crew of good staff. Turnover is unbelievable. It's a systemic problem throughout the company.

review_title: Bad experience but might help you start out in Social Work field
job_title: Child Care Worker in Chula Vista, CA
pros:
Some of the staff are great
Some of the children are fun to work with
You can gain experience working with children with mental health problems, but you might leave NA with mental problems ( see cons)
cons: Pay is too low. If you work here...be homeless or work another job. No raises. Pay is 13.50! Terrible for San Diego. Some of the senior staff don’t look out for you and are backstabbing. Some kids are vicious  and will injure you knowing that if you defend your self you go to jail. My last day at NA was in the hospital half way through my shift I was injured by a resident and sent to the hospital. Didn’t get paid for time on the job at hospital for job related injury. If you can avoid this place. You get treated like crap, have to do disgusting jobs here such as clean up filth and search dirty Landry. I have been spit on multiple times, bit multiple times, nails dig into me. Seen female staff get sexually assaulted by residents. This is a place that sets up troubled youth to be criminals.

review_title: Work here only if you really want to help at risk youth
pros: You build bonds with your coworkers and the kids, that is really why most people stay for so long.
cons:
Rules change all the time, it's hard to keep up.
They borderline make you lie in reports if your version of events doesn't match what they want you to say.
Stuff that is broken down in the residential units does not get fixed in a timely matter and when it does, most of the time it's temporary fixes in order to pass an audit. 
Almost always short staffed which leads to an increase of incidents. 
No paid holidays.
Low pay.
Don't want to offer over time.
Administration has unrealistic expectations and doesn't always support the residential staff.
No real structure in place to actually help the kids. It is way to easy for the kids who have the worst behaviors to impact the ones who behave well.
The school that most kids on campus go to is a complete joke.

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: All of the people I worked at were pretty great and always had your back (which was important when kids threatened to beat you up).  The training was pretty thorough and well done.
cons: The kids will break your heart.  Although most people work hard to do what they can with New Alternatives it will make you angry with the system in general.  It's like the kids are kept alive and fed and there's little more that can be done for them beyond that because of low funding and a pretty big difference in the behavior levels.  The bad kids ruin it for the good kids by taking up all of the attention, time and risk levels for doing fun activities etc.

review_title: Come for the Kids. Leave for the Leadership.
pros: The best thing about this mismanaged company is the children it serves and the dedicated direct care staff. The 5 plus years I was employed at N.A.I. afforded me the opportunity to meet and form solid friendships with peers and cultivate rewarding relationships with the residents.
cons: Aside from the low pay, which one would probably expect in the non profit sector, this company has gone from a leader in serving emotionally disturbed youth to one that prioritizes business over people. Imagine a place where people are afraid to voice opinions for fear of retaliation, where criticism trumps positive feedback and information is guarded and doled out not to inform, but control and sadly you have, in my opinion, New Alternatives.

pros: The bond you build with coworkers, an active position where you are not confined to a desk all day, lots of valuable experience gained, rewarding and challenging work
cons: Difficult client situations, poor physical working environment, management lacks proper follow-through and knowledge and abilities, no holidays off, business decisions sometimes made not in best interest of the youth, disorganization and inefficient workflow systems, lack of needed resources, no checks and balances in place regarding actually having an HR dept/compliance department, staff at times overworked and stressed, rash decisions made without consulting all concerned, favoritism

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chula Vista, CA
pros:
you can have overtime and double time if there is a crisis or if they need staff. 
you get to say you work at a high level of care.
you get to experience with  crisis interventions
cons:
everything.
You are emotionally abused at work meaning kids go crazy on you and you can get hurt really bad, you can get punched any day if something goes wrong. there is no consistency at all and the kids know this, they can hit someone and they still get rewards. If you work here you will develop anxiety and you will have trouble sleeping.

review_title: Child Care Worker - Great Job, Poor Support
job_title: Child Care Worker in Chula Vista, CA
pros: The connection you make with the clients really makes a difference. They become your children, and you make sure their needs are met appropriately. Your team of coworkers on your shift becomes your biggest support system, especially your shift supervisor. It is incredibly important to be a team player, because these people will save your life.
cons: Poor communication from administration to employees. Rules are constantly changing and very little training and direction is offered. With certain team members and shifts, it  may feel like you are attending high school instead of coming to work.

pros:
The kids are amazing, hard to deal with but a lot of fun. 
You can see the progress or change on them.
cons:
A lot of driving
You get more money working at jack in the box 13 per hour, not counting the hours driving to the kid's houses.
You start and you receive leftovers about working hours.
One co-worker was a two face high ego back stabbing type of person the others were fine.
The director is a mess, it is a miracle that the program works.
They care about foster parents and not about their staff. Some foster parents are terrible single parent with many kids, house a mess, cruel, but due to scarcity of foster parents they take care of them like if they were made of gold.

pros: Most of the nurses are great and really care about the kids. There are a few bad apples but that is to be expected anywhere.
cons: The management from the top down is simply awful. They are unethical, inept, and pressure nurses to do things that are unsafe and illegal.  Patient safety is nowhere near a priority and nurses have to push back against the social workers  (Directors) who prefer to put patients in unsafe situations in order to charge Medi-Cal for a warm body filling the bed.

review_title: Rivalry between departments aside from that focus on the kids is sincere and dedicated.
pros: They hire the type of people who have an earnest desire to help those in need and do their best to get the job done.
cons: Some of the directors of the facilities have been promoted from lower level positions from within but lack some formal education making it difficult for those who are being supervised by them (with higher education and professional training to do their jobs properly.

pros: New Alternatives is a great place to get experience and work with a collaborative team. The company has several facilities with different levels of care. Your team is often very supportive.
cons: Be aware of what level of care you are applying to. High turnover is common, so you should fee comfortable with a constantly changing team as employers are often in high stress situations and county funding becomes more limited.

review_title: Good experience for working with the population, but expect up to 75% paperwork
pros: You can come out of the experience with a deep knowledge about the population and crisis management experience.
cons: Lowest pay of most non-profits, poor management, super stressful work environment, high turnover, low morale.

review_title: The work is very tedious with little to no praises from supervisors.
